item.title: 1.1 Quickstart
item.description:
Introduction

As a newcomer to lifting weights, the first goal should be to learn and get good at the basic movement patterns.

  • A Vertical Pull (like Pullups)
  • A Horizontal Pull or a Row (like Barbell Rows)
  • A Horizontal Push (like Pushups)
  • A Squat Pattern
  • A Hip-Hinge (like Deadlifts)
  • An Overhead Press (like standing barbell overhead press).

Most people just wanna look good and feel strong, just getting stronger at the basics along with some isolation work should do that.

item.title: 1.2 Terminology
item.description:
Hypertrophy

A fancy word for muscle bulding.

Compound Movement

Any lift that involves two or more joints. Typically accompanied with two or more muscle groups being involved. Example, dips (chest, tricep, and front delt).

Isolation Movement

Only one joint is involved in the movement, usually accompanied with just one muscle. Example, tricep pushdown (tricep)

Progressive Overload

Increase in weights over time, to get the same stimulus for growth.

Hip-Hinges

A deadlift kind of movement, where the lower back is arched and the hip acts like a hinge.

item.title: 2.3 What builds muscle?
item.description:
Now that I’ve familiarized you with most of the basics concepts of training for hypertrophy, it’s time to realize what actually builds muscle.

Training a muscle for it’s function under mechanical load and tension till muscular failure gives a stimulus for growth. The protein and calories we consume is used to synthesize muscle, aided with with good sleep and recovery.

Essentially, we are breaking down the muscle fibres when we work out, and building it back when we eat and sleep, to slightly bigger size than before.
This repeated again and again over a period of months/years is what gives significant visible change in one’s physique.

item.title: Workout Protocol for Beginners
item.description:
Introduction

This section dives into various big muscles we have that we need to focus on, along with exploring their functions.
I’ll categorise muscles and movement patterns in terms of PUSH PULL and LEGS, so that it’s easier to follow.

  • Push
    • Chest
    • Front Delt
    • Tricep
  • Pull
    • Back
    • Bicep
    • Rear Delt
  • Legs
    • Quads
    • Hams
    • Glutes
    • Calves

Push

The musculature involved in pushing stuff away from us.
For Example, in Bench Press, you’re pressing/pushing the barbell away from yourself.
The following muscles are part of the pushing musclature:

item.title: Workout Protocol for Beginners
item.description:
Introduction

This section explores how to train a muscle group based on its functions.

  • Push
    • Chest
    • Front Delt
    • Tricep
  • Pull
    • Back
    • Bicep
    • Rear Delt
  • Legs
    • Quads
    • Hams
    • Glutes
    • Calves

Chest

The Main function of the chest is to press.

Chest Press

Movements like the barbell bench press, dips etc come over here, where we’re pressing the weight using our chest muscles.
Getting stronger at these builds the majority of the chest.

Good resources to learn from

Youtube Channels

Jeff Nipard Natural Hypertrophy Alex Leonidas Geoffery Verity Schofield Basement Bodybuilding Max Euceda

Podcasts
